Interviewer's evaluation: In the Direction or Memory section, did you record "Yes" (an indication of memory errors) or "Not applicable" frequently during the interview? Or was there a lot of "not applicable" in the rest of the interview? "
Taking everything into account, how would you describe your satisfaction with life at the present time: good, average, or weak?
In general, how happy are you: very happy, reasonably happy, not too happy, not happy at all?
* Interviewer's evaluation * Has the interview ended?
Face without expression. Does not show expressions during conversation.
Monotonous VOICE.  No play of expression in conversation.
No gesture accompanying speech
No appropriate emotion shown when delusional or normal material is discussed which would usually bring out emotion

Uniform blunting of mood, 
whatever the tone of conversation (indifference, apathetic acceptance).
Uncontrollable short bouts of crying.
Uncontrollable short bouts of laughing.
Elated, euphoric, even though perhaps changing to irritability or depression.
Infectious gaiety.
OTHER AFFECT: Facetious:  silly jokes, flippant remarks.
UNCO-OPERATIVE, ETC.: Tries to start an argument.
Choreiform movements (continuous, purposeless, jerky, involuntary movements of the head, body or limbs while at rest)
Athetoid movements (continuous, purposeless, slow writhing movements of tongue, jaws or limbs).
Parkinsonian movements (characteristic repeated regular tremor of the hands at rest.  Described as 'pill rolling', as if the interviewee was rolling a pill between the thumb and finger tips).
Obvious abnormality of walking.
Obvious evidence of paralysis or stroke.
Obvious evidence of physical abnormality of the legs like arthritis, amputation, or gross swelling.
Gait normal, just unsteady
Staggers as if drunk
Takes slow shuffling steps
Vague quality to speech.  No completion of a thought or idea.

Patient talks fairly freely, but vaguely and ambiguously so that ideas communicated are not clear - vague wandering from idea to idea or point to point, e.g.
Question:  
HOW DO YOU LIKE IT IN THE HOSPITAL?
Response:  
WELL, or ….NOT QUITE THE SAME AS, OR …DO NOT QUITE KNOW HOW TO SAY IT.  IT IS NOT THE SAME, BEING IN HOSPITAL AS, or....WORKING. ER….THE JOB IS NOT QUITE THE SAME or… VERY MUCH THE SAME, BUT OF COURSE, IT IS NOT EXACTLY THE SAME.
Irrelevance:  whole content of answer may have little to do with the question.  (Do not include wandering or rambling from the topic, or incoherence).
Circumstantial:  much unnecessary detail, but the object in view at the beginning is ultimately reached.
Rambling:  talks in an aimless fashion.  Object in view at the beginning is not reached.
rate of speech: Extremely rapid speech, but can be interrupted.
Pressure of speech:  too many words, rapid and keeps resisting interruption.

Flight of ideas:  one idea suggests another in rapid succession, so that patient is soon far from the point, e.g.
Question:  
WHAT IS THE TIME?
Response:  
IT IS THREE O'CLOCK BY MY H. SAMUEL EVERRIGHT GOLD WATCH, BUT IT IS NOT ON THE GOLD STANDARD, WAVE 
THE FLAGS A LIFE ON THE BRINY WAVE.
Speech very slow.  Distinct pauses between words.
Long pauses before replying a characteristic feature.

Perseveration: Repeats answer inappropriately
e.g.      Question:  Weekday?
            Response: Tuesday
            Questions:  Month?
            Response:   Tuesday
Judgment: Problems with memory are more prominent than problems with thinking i.e. more difficulty with remembering things than working things out.
Foreign language e.g. poor command of language in which interview is conducted interpreter required.
Unclear dialect or accent.
Dysarthria (due to speech organs) e.g. coarse tremor of the tongue or paralysis of vocal chords.
Deafness - severe.
Stuttering.
Weakness - severe.
Other.
Low intelligence.
Interview conditions unfavourable, e.g. noisy, distracting environment.
Patient appears generally sleepy, but does not actually fall asleep.
Memory defect (clear-cut) e.g. disorientated, gross memory loss, clear-cut blackout, etc.
Memory defect (dubious) e.g. hazy recall, unconvincingly claims not to remember, makes little attempt to recall.
Incoherent in clear consciousness (e.g. not sleepy) i.e. irrelevant or bizarre or random answers, disjointed ideas, gibberish, neologisms, perseveration, flight of ideas.
Keeps referring to delusions or hallucinations.
Incorporates interviewer in delusions.
Posturing (maintains an unusual or odd position of any part of the body repeatedly or for several minutes at a time) bizarre behaviour.
Speaks coherently to self; speaks to voices.
Cries uncontrollably.
Pressure of speech (cannot be interrupted in the usual manner, talks the interviewer down).
Gross suspiciousness.
Other.
Mutism not specified as due to physical defect.
Suspicious.  Negativistic (clearly does the opposite of what the interviewer asks or expects).
Withdrawal or apparent apathy possibly due to indifference OR to deep depression.
Over talkative, but not pressure of speech.
Lack of insight.  Total denial of symptoms or illness.
Excited or agitated or obviously elated (cannot sit still, or frequently interrupts with fatuous jokes or remarks).
Pre-occupied with inner experiences which are not vocalised (unspecified pre-occupation).
Distractibility (interviewee's attention is frequently drawn to trivial and irrelevant events in the environment).
Other.
